RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN Executive summary

UNION CARBIDE CORPORATION a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company
SOUTH CHARLESTON 

Union Carbide Corporation became a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company in 2001.  As such, all Union Carbide facilities now operate under and adhere to policies and standards of The Dow Chemical Company.  The Union Carbide facilities at South Charleston, Institute, Technology Park, North Charleston Distribution Terminal,and New Yard share leveraged support and management and are collectively called West Virginia Operations.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

West Virginia Operations is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release should occur, our highly trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  We are also completely coordinated with the Kanawha/Putnam Emergency Planning Committee which provides additional emergency response expertise.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The South Charleston site is a manufacturing facility that annually produces many different specialty chemicals and plastics.  Most are intermediates used in other processes or sold to customers who convert them into finished products.  Several RMP covered processes were closed just prior to the 2004 5-year RMP Update due to business reasons, and their related chemicals have been eliminated from Union CarbideA?s South Charleston facility.  Changes from the 2004 RMP submittal include the removal of: 
VME process containing Acetaldehyde, Crotonaldehyde [2-Butenal], and V

inyl methyl ether [Ethene, methoxy-]; AAA process containing Methylamane {methanamine], Dimethylamine [Methanamine, N-methyl-], and Ethylene Oxide [Oxirane].

The Gum Base Plant process (formerly named Poly Vinyl Acetate) was reported in the 2004 RMP Update as an eliminated process due to business reasons.  In December 2004, the gum base business climate changed and the demand for poly vinyl acetate increased.  A business decision was made to restart the Gum Base Plant.  The Gum base Plant (GBP) did re-start in 2005 and an updated RMP Plan was submitted to EPA.  The quantities of vinyl acetate monomer stored and handled at the South Charleston Plant did not increase from those reported in the 1999 RMP Plan.

Union Carbide handles and stores threshold quantities of the following RMP-regulated toxic substances at the South Charleston Plant:
Allyl Alcohol    
Ethylene Oxide      
Propylene Oxide
Vinyl Acetate Monomer

Due to the closure of the AAA process and the VME process, Union Carbide South Charleston site no longer handles or stores threshold quantities of the RMP-regulated flammable substances.  Thus flammable worst case and flammable alternate release scenarios have been removed from the 2009 RMP Update.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

South Charleston has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no accidental releases as defined by the RMP rule of regulated substances, during this period.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Union CarbideA?s general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA RMP rule, OSHAA?s PSM standard, and implementation of Dow's Operating Discipline Management System.  Key elements include:

Process Safety Information
We maintain a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include Material Safet

y Data Sheets for all the hazardous chemicals, Equipment Design Specification sheets, Reactive Chemicals Test results, and many others. This information is maintained up-to-date and is available to operating personnel.

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified, evaluated, and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses include: Checklists, What If/Checklists (combined),  Audits, Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analyses, Chemical Exposure Index, Fire & Explosion Index, and Layers of Protection Analyses. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.  

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Union Carbide Corporation maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training
Our facility has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided on a continuing basis.

Mechanical Integrity
We carry out a highly documented Planned Preventative Maintenance Program (PPM) which provides checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps, and compressors.  Maintenance operati

ons are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change
Union Carbide facilities require management of all modifications to process equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions other than "like for like", by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation of changes.   Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and are trained to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Union Carbide. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Self assessments and audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  Audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
Union Carbide promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a significant release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Union Carbide Corporation believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views c

oncerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facilityA?s implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors
Our company hires contractors to perform specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is performed.  West Virginia Operations has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractorA?s work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Kanawha/Putnam Emergency Planning Committee and the community.

The South Charleston facility carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.

To ensure proper functioning, quarterly emergency drills are conducted to enhance skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release.  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.  Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition to the on-site emergency squad, Union Carbide staffs a Distribution Emergency Resp

onse Team (DERT) in the Kanawha Valley that responds to accidental releases from transportation equipment throughout the continental United States

Kanawha/Putnam EPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several projects with the goal of improving process safety have been implanted since the 2004 RMP submittal:
A?South Charleston facility has been part of the EPA Performance Track program since 2002.  The South Charleston Plant initially received OSHA VPP Star Certification in 2005 and was re-certified in August 2008.
A?Process code control changes:
    A?Vent interlock to prevent volatile venting at elevated temperatures.
    A?Residual oxide control to ensure no loss of cooling.
    A?Feed interlocks to ensure cooling in the event of high river water temperature.
A?Dead-head pump protection improvements A? small improvements to over 100 pumps to reduce symptoms caused by deadhead situations.
A?Installation of improved backpressure regulators that do not allow diaphragm leaks.
A?Upgrade of the vinyl acetate monomer storage tank internal floating roof seal to a new stainless steel shoe in compliance with the MON rule.  All internal floating roof seals and gaskets were replaced and the new installation inspected and reviewed/approved by management of change procedures.
A?Implementation of DowA?s Safety System Impairment Standard which defines the requirements and work practices necessary to impair safety systems while in operation for testing or maintenance of the safety system.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY/Process Safety
A?Install new seal system in 8390 pump to improve reliability.
A?Fall protection systems A? installation of several safety cage systems on rail-car and tank truck loading/unloading racks, plus fall protection improvements at selected process mixing tanks.
